elements.content: The design and synthesis of polymeric metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has for a long time been a challenging field for coordination chemists, owing to the relative difficulty of synthesizing new compounds. An effective method to construct MOFs is the self-assembly of the inorganic second building units (SBUs) and the organic linker molecules [31]. N,N′-bis(substituent)oxamides, as versatile bridging ligands, of which the trans conformation with vacant coordinated sites is more stable than the cis one in the lack of steric hindrance between the substituents on the amine nitrogen atom, allow the formation of trans-oxamidato-bridged binuclear SBUs [32]. Hence this family of ligands has played important role in constructing polymeric MOFs. Apart from the inorganic SBUs, the organic linker molecules with versatile coordination modes are also indispensable to construct the polymeric MOFs. The benzene dicarboxylate dianions, due to their versatile bonding modes with metal ions and their peculiar structures, involving carboxylate groups that are non-coplanar with themselves and with the benzene ring, could be good candidates for the preparation of polymeric MOFs [23, 33–35]. So far, many of new metal-polymers with interesting structures based on the bridging N,N′-bis(substituent)oxamides have been synthesized and their properties have been studied extensively [36, 37]. However, the structures of reported those polymeric MOFs involving coordinating hydroxy groups in the N,N′-bis(substituent)oxamide bridging ligand appear to be rare. In this paper, we chose N,N′-bis(N-hydroxyethylaminoethyl)oxamide (H2heae) to synthesize the SBU with the trans-heae-bridged binuclear copper(II) building block [Cu2(heae)]2+. And then tpa is used as the organic linker molecule attaching the binuclear copper(II) building blocks to form a 1D copper(II) coordination polymeric complex [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n·nH2O. The synthetic pathway for the complexation may be represented by Scheme 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Route and General Properties of the Polymer

The design and synthesis of polymeric metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has for a long time been a challenging field for coordination chemists, owing to the relative difficulty of synthesizing new compounds. An effective method to construct MOFs is the self-assembly of the inorganic second building units (SBUs) and the organic linker molecules [31]. N,N'-bis(substituent)oxamides, as versatile bridging ligands, of which the trans conformation with vacant coordinated sites is more stable than the cis one in the lack of steric hindrance between the substituents on the amine nitrogen atom, allow the formation of trans-oxamidato-bridged binuclear SBUs [32]. Hence this family of ligands has played important role in constructing polymeric MOFs. Apart from the inorganic SBUs, the organic linker molecules with versatile coordination modes are also indispensable to construct the polymeric MOFs. The benzene dicarboxylate dianions, due to their versatile bonding modes with metal ions and their peculiar structures, involving carboxylate groups that are non-coplanar with themselves and with the benzene ring, could be good candidates for the preparation of polymeric MOFs [23, 33-35]. So far, many of new metal-polymers with interesting structures based on the bridging N,N'-bis(substituent)oxamides have been synthesized and their properties have been studied extensively [36, 37]. However, the structures of reported those polymeric MOFs involving coordinating hydroxy groups in the N,N'-bis(substituent)oxamide bridging ligand appear to be rare. In this paper, we chose N,N'-bis(N-hydroxyethylaminoethyl)oxamide (H2heae) to synthesize the SBU with the trans-heae-bridged binuclear copper(II) building block [Cu2(heae)]2+. And then tpa is used as the organic linker molecule attaching the binuclear copper(II) building blocks to form a 1D copper(II) coordination polymeric complex [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n⋅nH2O. The synthetic pathway for the complexation may be represented by Scheme 1.

elements.content: The polymeric copper(II) complex is both insoluble in non-polar solvents and common polar solvents, moderately soluble in water, methanol and acetonitrile, and very soluble in DMF and DMSO to give stable solutions at room temperature, implying the polymeric nature of the complex [38]. In the solid state the complex is fairly stable in air allowing physical measurements. The molar conductance value of the polymeric copper(II) complex (Λ = 20 Ω−1 cm−2 mol−1 in DMF solution) falls in the expected range for non-electrolyte [39], suggesting that all of the tpa ligands in the copper(II) polymer have been involved with the coordination. Indeed, it is difficult to determine whether the polymer stays intact in solution as the 1D polymer in the crystal structure. The possibility of the polymer falling apart is not ruled out. However, the molar conductivity in solution suggests that the polymeric copper(II) complex is intact as the whole, neutral polymer entity [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n. This viewpoint is further evidenced by some 1D copper(II) coordination polymers with similar polymeric characteristics [36].

The molar conductance value of the polymeric copper(II) complex (Λ = 20 Ω-1 cm-2 mol-1 in DMF solution) falls in the expected range for non-electrolyte [39], suggesting that all of the tpa ligands in the copper(II) polymer have been involved with the coordination. Indeed, it is difficult to determine whether the polymer stays intact in solution as the 1D polymer in the crystal structure. The possibility of the polymer falling apart is not ruled out. However, the molar conductivity in solution suggests that the polymeric copper(II) complex is intact as the whole, neutral polymer entity [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n. This viewpoint is further evidenced by some 1D copper(II) coordination polymers with similar polymeric characteristics [36].

elements.content: In the IR spectrum of the complex, the N–H and O–H vibrations of the bridging oxamidate ligand appear in the 3,202 and 3,490 cm−1, respectively. And the carbonyl stretching vibration is observed at 1,655 cm−1 in the complex, which is characteristic of the bridging oxamidate group [40]. The copper(II) polymer also exhibits characteristic vibration bands of νas(COO) (1,578 cm−1) and νs(COO) (1,314 cm−1). The Δ value, which represents the separation of νas(COO) and νs(COO), reflects the coordination modes of the carboxyl groups [41]. The Δ value (264 cm−1) indicating that the carboxyl groups on tpa ligand behave as mono-dentate ligands in the copper(II) polymer [41].
elements.clean_text:
IR and Electronic Spectra

In the IR spectrum of the complex, the N-H and O-H vibrations of the bridging oxamidate ligand appear in the 3,202 and 3,490 cm-1, respectively. And the carbonyl stretching vibration is observed at 1,655 cm-1 in the complex, which is characteristic of the bridging oxamidate group [40]. The copper(II) polymer also exhibits characteristic vibration bands of νas(COO) (1,578 cm-1) and νs(COO) (1,314 cm-1). The Δ value, which represents the separation of νas(COO) and νs(COO), reflects the coordination modes of the carboxyl groups [41]. The Δ value (264 cm-1) indicating that the carboxyl groups on tpa ligand behave as mono-dentate ligands in the copper(II) polymer [41].

elements.content: The electronic spectra of the copper(II) polymer were recorded in the UV–Visible. The copper(II) polymer shows three absorption bands with varied intensities. The intense band at 203 nm is assigned to intra-ligand (π–π*) transition associated to tpa ligand. While the less intense band at 275 nm corresponds to the charge transfer transition from tpa ligand to the metals. Besides, the broad band observed at the lower frequency of 645 nm in the spectrum matches well with the reported d–d transition of five-coordinated copper(II) in the square-pyramidal geometry [42]. The spectroscopic data of the copper(II) polymer are in agreement with the determination of the crystal structure (vide infra).

elements.content: The X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis indicates that the copper(II) complex consists of a neutral one-dimensional chain, [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n·nH2O, which is formed by trans-heae binuclear copper(II) complex cations, [Cu2(heae)]2+, as the inorganic SBUs further connected by the linkers, tpa2− anions in end-to-end fashion. The dissymmetric unit contains a complex cation coordinated to a tpa2− anion and a crystallized water molecule as shown in Fig. 1. The selected geometric parameters are summarized in Table 2.

The X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis indicates that the copper(II) complex consists of a neutral one-dimensional chain, [Cu2(heae)(tpa)]n⋅nH2O, which is formed by trans-heae binuclear copper(II) complex cations, [Cu2(heae)]2+, as the inorganic SBUs further connected by the linkers, tpa2- anions in end-to-end fashion. The dissymmetric unit contains a complex cation coordinated to a tpa2- anion and a crystallized water molecule as shown in Fig. 1. The selected geometric parameters are summarized in Table 2.

Both copper(II) ions have {N2O3} square pyramidal coordination geometries with τ values [43] of 0.049 (Cu1) and 0.019 (Cu2). Their basal planes are composed of two nitrogen atoms and an oxygen atom from heae2− ligand and one carboxyl oxygen atom of tpa2−. And their apical positions are occupied by hydroxyl oxygen atoms of heae2− ligand. Atoms Cu1 and Cu2 displace from the basal planes 0.0576(13) and 0.0980(13) Å, respectively. The bond lengths of Cu–N and Cu–O in Table 2 are close to those found in other oxamido-bridged copper(II) complexes [44–48]. The axial Cu–O bonds are longer than those in the basal plane. The differences are 0.401(3) and 0.333(3) Å for atom Cu1 and 0.343(3) and 0.262(3) Å for atom Cu2. The bond lengths of Cu1–N2 and Cu2–N3 are shorter than Cu1–N1 and Cu2–N4, which is consistent with stronger donor ability of the oxamide nitrogen atoms compared with amine ones.

elements.content: The trans-oxamide bridge, heae2−, as a bis-tetradentate ligand chelates both copper(II) ions with three five-membered rings respectively. The rings formed by oxamide-bridge are planar as usual with the Cu–Cu separation of 5.2472(6) Å. Those formed by ethylenediamine groups adopt the twist conformation with the puckering parameters [49] of Q = 0.437(3) Å, φ = 54.7(4)º for atom Cu1 and Q = 0.431(4) Å, φ = 301.3(4)º for atom Cu2. While those formed by hydroxyethylamine groups are in envelope, the corresponding puckering parameters are Q = 0.530(3) Å, φ = 78.9(3)º for atom Cu1 and Q = 0.495(4) Å, φ = 251.9(3)º for atom Cu2. The other bridging ligand, tpa2− anion, bis-monodentately coordinates to two copper(II) ions with Cu···Cu distance of 10.9677(8) Å. The dihedral angles between the carboxyl groups and benzene ring are 5.35(14)º (C18) and 20.83(12)º (C11).

elements.content: In the crystal, the complex chain extends parallel to the b axis. These 1D chains are connected into a 2D network by the classical O–H···O hydrogen-bond between hydroxyl groups and carboxyl groups (Fig. 2; Table 3). Subsequently, the 2D layers are further linked with hydrogen bonds of lattice water molecules to yield a 3D supramolecular structure.

The cytotoxicity assays of the polymeric copper(II) complex and cis-platin against two cancer cell lines human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC-7721 and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 were conducted in our study. It is noteworthy that the IC50 values of the polymeric copper(II) complex are 19.0 ± 0.3 and 11.0 ± 0.4 μM for SMMC-7721 and A549, respectively, which are much higher than those of cis-platin (5.4 ± 0.2 μM for SMMC-7721 and 7.6 ± 0.4 μM for A549), indicating that the cytotoxic activity of the polymeric copper(II) complex is less than that of cis-platin. However, the inhibition of cell proliferation produced by the polymeric copper(II) complex on the same batch of cell lines is still rather active. The polymeric copper(II) complex possessing cytotoxic activity may be attributed to the extended planar structure induced by the p–π* conjugation from the chelation of the metal ion with the ligands. These findings of cytotoxic activities in vitro prompt us to explore the DNA-binding studies on the polymeric copper(II) complex.
elements.clean_text:
Cytotoxic Activity of the Polymeric Copper(II) Complex

The cytotoxicity assays of the polymeric copper(II) complex and cis-platin against two cancer cell lines human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC-7721 and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 were conducted in our study. It is noteworthy that the IC50 values of the polymeric copper(II) complex are 19.0 ± 0.3 and 11.0 ± 0.4 μM for SMMC-7721 and A549, respectively, which are much higher than those of cis-platin (5.4 ± 0.2 μM for SMMC-7721 and 7.6 ± 0.4 μM for A549), indicating that the cytotoxic activity of the polymeric copper(II) complex is less than that of cis-platin. However, the inhibition of cell proliferation produced by the polymeric copper(II) complex on the same batch of cell lines is still rather active. The polymeric copper(II) complex possessing cytotoxic activity may be attributed to the extended planar structure induced by the p-π* conjugation from the chelation of the metal ion with the ligands. These findings of cytotoxic activities in vitro prompt us to explore the DNA-binding studies on the polymeric copper(II) complex.

elements.content: Electronic absorption spectroscopy is an effective method to examine the binding modes and binding extent of the metal complexes with DNA. The hypochromism and red shift are generally associated with the binding of the metal complexes to the DNA helix, due to the intercalative mode involving a strong stacking interaction between the aromatic chromophore of the complexes and the base pairs of DNA. The electronic absorption spectra of the polymeric copper(II) complex in the absence and presence of HS-DNA are shown in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, when titrated by HS-DNA, the band centered at 203 nm exhibits hypochromism accompanied with a red-shift of 5 nm. Obviously, these spectral characteristics reveal that the polymeric copper(II) complex interacts with HS-DNA through the intercalation mode that involves π–π stacking interaction between the aromatic chromophore and the base pairs of the DNA. These spectral changes are analogous to that of our previously reported a one-dimensional copper(II) polymer with formula of [Cu2(H2O)2(dmapox)(tpa)2]n [50], whose interaction mode with DNA is intercalative binding. These observations for the polymeric copper(II) complex can be rationalized by the following reasons. When the polymeric copper(II) complex intercalates the base pairs of HS-DNA, the π*-orbital of the intercalated ligands in the polymeric copper(II) complex can couple with the π-orbital of the base pairs, thus decreasing the π–π* transition energy and resulting in the bathochromism. Furthermore, the coupling π-orbital is partially filled by electrons, thus decreasing the transition probabilities and concomitantly resulting in hypochromism.
elements.clean_text:
DNA-Binding Studies

Electronic Absorption Titration

Electronic absorption spectroscopy is an effective method to examine the binding modes and binding extent of the metal complexes with DNA. The hypochromism and red shift are generally associated with the binding of the metal complexes to the DNA helix, due to the intercalative mode involving a strong stacking interaction between the aromatic chromophore of the complexes and the base pairs of DNA. The electronic absorption spectra of the polymeric copper(II) complex in the absence and presence of HS-DNA are shown in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, when titrated by HS-DNA, the band centered at 203 nm exhibits hypochromism accompanied with a red-shift of 5 nm. Obviously, these spectral characteristics reveal that the polymeric copper(II) complex interacts with HS-DNA through the intercalation mode that involves π-π stacking interaction between the aromatic chromophore and the base pairs of the DNA. These spectral changes are analogous to that of our previously reported a one-dimensional copper(II) polymer with formula of [Cu2(H2O)2(dmapox)(tpa)2]n [50], whose interaction mode with DNA is intercalative binding. These observations for the polymeric copper(II) complex can be rationalized by the following reasons. When the polymeric copper(II) complex intercalates the base pairs of HS-DNA, the π*-orbital of the intercalated ligands in the polymeric copper(II) complex can couple with the π-orbital of the base pairs, thus decreasing the π-π* transition energy and resulting in the bathochromism. Furthermore, the coupling π-orbital is partially filled by electrons, thus decreasing the transition probabilities and concomitantly resulting in hypochromism.

elements.content: In order to quantitatively evaluate the binding strength of the copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, the intrinsic binding constant Kb was determined by monitoring the changes in absorbance at 203 nm using the following equation [51]:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{a}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) = \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) + 1/K_{\text{b}} \left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) $$\end{document}where [DNA] is the concentration of DNA, εf, εa and εb correspond to the extinction coefficient, respectively, for the free polymeric copper(II) complex, for each addition of DNA to the polymeric copper(II) complex and for the polymeric copper(II) complex in the fully bound form. As shown in Fig. 3b, in the plot of [DNA]/(εa−εf) versus [DNA], the binding constant Kb for the polymeric copper(II) complex was estimated to be 1.07 × 104 M−1, (R = 0.9911 for nine points), lower than those of typical intercalators (e.g., EB-DNA, ~106 M−1) [52], and has the same level as those of well-established intercalation agents [53].

elements.content: To further investigate the interaction mode between the polymeric copper(II) complex and HS-DNA, the EB fluorescence displacement experiments were used. In general, the intrinsic fluorescence intensity of DNA is very low, and that of EB in Tris–HCl buffer is also not high due to quenching by the solvent molecules. However, on addition of DNA, the fluorescence intensity of EB will be enhanced because of its intercalation into the DNA. Thus, EB can be used to probe the interaction of complexes with DNA. If the complexes can intercalate into DNA, the binding sites of DNA available for EB will be decreased, and hence the fluorescence intensity of EB will be quenched [54]. In our experiment, it has been used to monitor the interaction of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the fluorescence intensity of EB at 584 nm shows an obvious decreasing trend with the increasing concentration of the polymeric copper(II) complex, suggesting that the polymeric copper(II) complex binds strongly with HS-DNA. The quenching of EB bound to DNA by polymeric copper(II) complex is in agreement with the linear Stern–Volmer equation [55]:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ I_{0} /I = 1+ K_{\text{sv}} \left[ {\text{Q}} \right] $$\end{document}where I0 and I represent the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, respectively. Ksv is a linear Stern–Volmer quenching constant, Q is the concentration of quencher. In the quenching plot (see inset in Fig. 4b) of I0/I versus (complex), Ksv is given by the ratio of the slope to intercept. The Ksv value for the polymeric copper(II) complex is 6.14 × 104 (R = 0.9927 for 14 points).

The Ethidium Bromide Fluorescence Displacement Experiments

To further investigate the interaction mode between the polymeric copper(II) complex and HS-DNA, the EB fluorescence displacement experiments were used. In general, the intrinsic fluorescence intensity of DNA is very low, and that of EB in Tris-HCl buffer is also not high due to quenching by the solvent molecules. However, on addition of DNA, the fluorescence intensity of EB will be enhanced because of its intercalation into the DNA. Thus, EB can be used to probe the interaction of complexes with DNA. If the complexes can intercalate into DNA, the binding sites of DNA available for EB will be decreased, and hence the fluorescence intensity of EB will be quenched [54]. In our experiment, it has been used to monitor the interaction of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the fluorescence intensity of EB at 584 nm shows an obvious decreasing trend with the increasing concentration of the polymeric copper(II) complex, suggesting that the polymeric copper(II) complex binds strongly with HS-DNA. The quenching of EB bound to DNA by polymeric copper(II) complex is in agreement with the linear Stern-Volmer equation [55]:2\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ I_{0} /I = 1+ K_{\text{sv}} \left[ {\text{Q}} \right] $$\end{document}where I0 and I represent the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, respectively. Ksv is a linear Stern-Volmer quenching constant, Q is the concentration of quencher. In the quenching plot (see inset in Fig. 4b) of I0/I versus (complex), Ksv is given by the ratio of the slope to intercept. The Ksv value for the polymeric copper(II) complex is 6.14 × 104 (R = 0.9927 for 14 points).

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetry (CV) has been widely employed to study DNA-binding properties for complexes with electronic activity, whether the electrochemical processes are reversible [56], quasi-reversible [57], or irreversible [58, 59]. In order to get a deeper insight into the mutual donor–acceptor electronic influence, we have undertaken CV studies of the copper(II) polymer. The cyclic voltammograms of the polymer (1.0 × 10−5 mol L−1) at different scan rates (from 0.06 to 0.24 V/s) were investigated (Supporting information, Fig. S1). The results indicated that the oxidation and reduction peak currents (ipa and ipc) both exhibit the linear relationship versus the scan rate (ipc = 3.4436 × 10−6 + 7.198 × 10−7 v, R = 0.9663; ipa = −2.966 × 10−7−7.835 × 10−7 v, R = 0.9707). These relationships indicate that the electrode processes in Tris–HCl buffer solution are absorption controlled [60].
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic Voltammetric Studies

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) has been widely employed to study DNA-binding properties for complexes with electronic activity, whether the electrochemical processes are reversible [56], quasi-reversible [57], or irreversible [58, 59]. In order to get a deeper insight into the mutual donor-acceptor electronic influence, we have undertaken CV studies of the copper(II) polymer. The cyclic voltammograms of the polymer (1.0 × 10-5 mol L-1) at different scan rates (from 0.06 to 0.24 V/s) were investigated (Supporting information, Fig. S1). The results indicated that the oxidation and reduction peak currents (ipa and ipc) both exhibit the linear relationship versus the scan rate (ipc = 3.4436 × 10-6 + 7.198 × 10-7 v, R = 0.9663; ipa = -2.966 × 10-7-7.835 × 10-7 v, R = 0.9707). These relationships indicate that the electrode processes in Tris-HCl buffer solution are absorption controlled [60].

elements.content: For exploring the binding mode between the polymeric copper(II) complex and HS-DNA, restricting the scan rate to 0.24 V/s, the CV behaviors of the copper(II) polymer (1.0 × 10−5 mol L−1) without and with different HS-DNA concentrations are studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 5. From this figure, it can be seen that with the increasing concentration of HS-DNA, the voltammetric peak currents decreased apparently, indicating that there exists an interaction between the copper(II) polymer and HS-DNA [61]. The shift in E0’ can be used to estimate the ratio of binding constants for reduced and oxidized forms to DNA using following equation [62]:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \Updelta E^{0\prime } = E_{b}^{0\prime } --E_{f}^{0\prime } = 5 9. 1 5 {\text{log}}\left( {K_{R} /K_{O} } \right) $$\end{document}where \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ E_{b}^{0\prime } $$\end{document} and \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ E_{f}^{0\prime } $$\end{document} are the formal potentials of the bound and free copper(II) complex forms, respectively, and KR and KO are the corresponding binding constants for the binding of reduction and oxidation species to HS-DNA, respectively. The ratio of constants for the binding of the Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions to HS-DNA was estimated to be 1.37 in presence of HS-DNA with R = 4 [R = (DNA)/(complex)], suggesting the stronger binding affinity in the Cu(I) state compared to the Cu(II) state for the polymeric copper(II) complex. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the Ebo′ value of the copper(II) complex is slightly shifted, indicating that the copper(II) complex could bind intercalatively to HS-DNA [62], which is in agreement with the above spectral results.

elements.content: To clarify further the interaction mode of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, viscosity measurements were applied. In classical intercalation the DNA helix lengthens as base pairs are separated to accommodate the bound ligand leading to increased DNA viscosity [63], whereas in groove binding or electrostatic mode the length of the helix unchanged results in not apparent alteration in DNA viscosity [64, 65]. Therefore viscosity measurement is regarded as the least ambiguous and the most critical means studying the binding mode of metal complexes with DNA in solution and provides stronger arguments for intercalative binding mode [64, 65]. The effects of the copper(II) complex on the viscosity of HS-DNA are shown in Fig. 6. As illustrated in this figure, viscosity experiment result indicates that the polymeric copper(II) complex increases the viscosity of HS-DNA, consistent with classical mode of intercalation. The result accords with the above conclusions.
elements.clean_text:
Viscosity Measurements

To clarify further the interaction mode of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, viscosity measurements were applied. In classical intercalation the DNA helix lengthens as base pairs are separated to accommodate the bound ligand leading to increased DNA viscosity [63], whereas in groove binding or electrostatic mode the length of the helix unchanged results in not apparent alteration in DNA viscosity [64, 65]. Therefore viscosity measurement is regarded as the least ambiguous and the most critical means studying the binding mode of metal complexes with DNA in solution and provides stronger arguments for intercalative binding mode [64, 65]. The effects of the copper(II) complex on the viscosity of HS-DNA are shown in Fig. 6. As illustrated in this figure, viscosity experiment result indicates that the polymeric copper(II) complex increases the viscosity of HS-DNA, consistent with classical mode of intercalation. The result accords with the above conclusions.

cln_elements.content: A methanol and acetonitrile (v/v = 1:1) solution (5 mL) of copper(II) chloride dihydrate (17.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added dropwise to the same solution (5 mL) containing H2heae (13.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) and piperidine (8.5 mg, 0.1 mmol). The mixture was stirred quickly for 30 min, then an aqueous solution (5 mL) of terephthalic acid (11.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) and piperidine (17.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise into the mixture. The reaction solution was heated under reflux with stirring at 333 K for 6 h. The resulting blue precipitates were collected, washed with water and dried in the desiccator. Yield: 71 %. Then the precipitates were dissolving in water. Deep bluish-green crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained from the solution after 40 days by slow evaporation at room temperature. Anal. Calcd. (%) for Cu2C18H26N4O9: C, 37.83; H, 4.94; N, 9.80. Found (%): C, 37.87; H, 4.90; N, 9.79.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Copper(II) Polymer

A methanol and acetonitrile (v/v = 1:1) solution (5 mL) of copper(II) chloride dihydrate (17.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added dropwise to the same solution (5 mL) containing H2heae (13.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) and piperidine (8.5 mg, 0.1 mmol). The mixture was stirred quickly for 30 min, then an aqueous solution (5 mL) of terephthalic acid (11.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) and piperidine (17.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise into the mixture. The reaction solution was heated under reflux with stirring at 333 K for 6 h. The resulting blue precipitates were collected, washed with water and dried in the desiccator. Yield: 71 %. Then the precipitates were dissolving in water. Deep bluish-green crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained from the solution after 40 days by slow evaporation at room temperature. Anal. Calcd. (%) for Cu2C18H26N4O9: C, 37.83; H, 4.94; N, 9.80. Found (%): C, 37.87; H, 4.90; N, 9.79.

cln_elements.content:
The electronic spectra of the copper(II) polymer were recorded in the UV–Visible. The copper(II) polymer shows three absorption bands with varied intensities. The intense band at 203 nm is assigned to intra-ligand (π–π*) transition associated to tpa ligand. While the less intense band at 275 nm corresponds to the charge transfer transition from tpa ligand to the metals. Besides, the broad band observed at the lower frequency of 645 nm in the spectrum matches well with the reported d–d transition of five-coordinated copper(II) in the square-pyramidal geometry [42]. The spectroscopic data of the copper(II) polymer are in agreement with the determination of the crystal structure (vide infra).

Cytotoxic Activity of the Polymeric Copper(II) Complex

The cytotoxicity assays of the polymeric copper(II) complex and cis-platin against two cancer cell lines human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC-7721 and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 were conducted in our study. It is noteworthy that the IC50 values of the polymeric copper(II) complex are 19.0 ± 0.3 and 11.0 ± 0.4 μM for SMMC-7721 and A549, respectively, which are much higher than those of cis-platin (5.4 ± 0.2 μM for SMMC-7721 and 7.6 ± 0.4 μM for A549), indicating that the cytotoxic activity of the polymeric copper(II) complex is less than that of cis-platin. However, the inhibition of cell proliferation produced by the polymeric copper(II) complex on the same batch of cell lines is still rather active. The polymeric copper(II) complex possessing cytotoxic activity may be attributed to the extended planar structure induced by the p–π* conjugation from the chelation of the metal ion with the ligands. These findings of cytotoxic activities in vitro prompt us to explore the DNA-binding studies on the polymeric copper(II) complex.

In order to quantitatively evaluate the binding strength of the copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, the intrinsic binding constant Kb was determined by monitoring the changes in absorbance at 203 nm using the following equation [51]:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{a}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) = \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) + 1/K_{\text{b}} \left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) $$\end{document}where [DNA] is the concentration of DNA, εf, εa and εb correspond to the extinction coefficient, respectively, for the free polymeric copper(II) complex, for each addition of DNA to the polymeric copper(II) complex and for the polymeric copper(II) complex in the fully bound form. As shown in Fig. 3b, in the plot of [DNA]/(εa−εf) versus [DNA], the binding constant Kb for the polymeric copper(II) complex was estimated to be 1.07 × 104 M−1, (R = 0.9911 for nine points), lower than those of typical intercalators (e.g., EB-DNA, ~106 M−1) [52], and has the same level as those of well-established intercalation agents [53].

The Ethidium Bromide Fluorescence Displacement Experiments

To further investigate the interaction mode between the polymeric copper(II) complex and HS-DNA, the EB fluorescence displacement experiments were used. In general, the intrinsic fluorescence intensity of DNA is very low, and that of EB in Tris–HCl buffer is also not high due to quenching by the solvent molecules. However, on addition of DNA, the fluorescence intensity of EB will be enhanced because of its intercalation into the DNA. Thus, EB can be used to probe the interaction of complexes with DNA. If the complexes can intercalate into DNA, the binding sites of DNA available for EB will be decreased, and hence the fluorescence intensity of EB will be quenched [54]. In our experiment, it has been used to monitor the interaction of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the fluorescence intensity of EB at 584 nm shows an obvious decreasing trend with the increasing concentration of the polymeric copper(II) complex, suggesting that the polymeric copper(II) complex binds strongly with HS-DNA. The quenching of EB bound to DNA by polymeric copper(II) complex is in agreement with the linear Stern–Volmer equation [55]:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ I_{0} /I = 1+ K_{\text{sv}} \left[ {\text{Q}} \right] $$\end{document}where I0 and I represent the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, respectively. Ksv is a linear Stern–Volmer quenching constant, Q is the concentration of quencher. In the quenching plot (see inset in Fig. 4b) of I0/I versus (complex), Ksv is given by the ratio of the slope to intercept. The Ksv value for the polymeric copper(II) complex is 6.14 × 104 (R = 0.9927 for 14 points).

Cyclic Voltammetric Studies

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) has been widely employed to study DNA-binding properties for complexes with electronic activity, whether the electrochemical processes are reversible [56], quasi-reversible [57], or irreversible [58, 59]. In order to get a deeper insight into the mutual donor–acceptor electronic influence, we have undertaken CV studies of the copper(II) polymer. The cyclic voltammograms of the polymer (1.0 × 10−5 mol L−1) at different scan rates (from 0.06 to 0.24 V/s) were investigated (Supporting information, Fig. S1). The results indicated that the oxidation and reduction peak currents (ipa and ipc) both exhibit the linear relationship versus the scan rate (ipc = 3.4436 × 10−6 + 7.198 × 10−7 v, R = 0.9663; ipa = −2.966 × 10−7−7.835 × 10−7 v, R = 0.9707). These relationships indicate that the electrode processes in Tris–HCl buffer solution are absorption controlled [60].

metadata.title: Synthesis, Structure, Cytotoxic Activities and DNA-Binding Properties of a 1D Copper(II) Complex Bridged both by Oxamidate and Terephthalato Groups
